sime

Class Link

  • java.lang.Object
    • sime.NetworkElement
      • sime.Link

  • public class Link
extends NetworkElement
    A full-duplex communication link that connects two network nodes. Packets that are fed on one end will come out at the other end of the link, after appropriate delays. The link has associated transmission and propagation times.
    Author:
    Ivan Marsic
    See Also:
    NetworkElement

    • Field Detail

      • lastTimeProcessCalledMode1

        protected double lastTimeProcessCalledMode1
        Parameters that override NetworkElement.lastTimeProcessCalled because Link has different modes of processing.

      • lastTimeProcessCalledMode2

        protected double lastTimeProcessCalledMode2

      • node1

        protected NetworkElement node1
        Nodes node1 and node2 connected by this link.

      • node2

        protected NetworkElement node2

      • packetDelaysN1toN2

        protected double[] packetDelaysN1toN2
        Delay times for packets stored in the list packetsFromN1toN2, in simulation-clock ticks. The delay for each packet is calculated when the packet is received in send(NetworkElement, Packet) and the delay is decremented in process(int) until it reaches zero. At this time, the packet is delivered to node2.

      • packetDelaysN2toN1

        protected double[] packetDelaysN2toN1
        Similar to packetDelaysN1toN2.

      • packetsFromN1toN2

        protected java.util.ArrayList<Packet> packetsFromN1toN2
        Container for packets in transit from node1 to node2.
        We never check whether this array overflows, because we hope there will be never more than 100 packets in flight on a link?!?

      • packetsFromN2toN1

        protected java.util.ArrayList<Packet> packetsFromN2toN1
        Container for packets in transit from node2 to node1.
        Similar to packetsFromN1toN2.

      • propagationTime

        protected double propagationTime
        Propagation time for this communication link. Measured in ticks of the simulator clock.

      • transmissionTime

        protected double transmissionTime
        Transmission time for this communication link (per packet, assuming all packets are of the same size!). The time is measured in ticks of the simulator clock.

    • Method Detail

      • deliverArrivedPackets

        protected void deliverArrivedPackets(java.util.ArrayList<Packet> packets_,
                         double[] packetDelays_,
                         NetworkElement node_,
                         double lastTimeProcessCalled_)
        Helper method to deliver the packets that propagated through the link and arrived to the other end, if any.
        Note that we assume that the packets are enqueued on the first-come-first-served basis, so their delays are sorted in an ascending order.
        Parameters:
        packets_ - the list of packets
        packetDelays_ - the array of delays associated with packets
        node_ - the node to which the arrived packets will be delivered
        lastTimeProcessCalled_ -

      • enqueueNewPacket

        protected void enqueueNewPacket(java.util.ArrayList<Packet> packets_,
                    double[] packetDelays_,
                    Packet packet_)
        Helper method to enqueue a new packet into one of the lists and calculate its delay on the link.
        Parameters:
        packets_ - the list of packets
        packetDelays_ - the array of delays associated with packets
        packet_ - the new packet to enqueue

      • handle

        public void handle(NetworkElement dummySource_,
          Packet dummyPacket_)
        Link does not "handle" incoming packets, so this method does nothing.
        Specified by:
        handle in class NetworkElement

        dummySource_ - this dummy parameter is ignored
        dummyPacket_ - this dummy parameter is ignored
        See Also:
        NetworkElement.handle(NetworkElement, sime.Packet)

      • process

        public void process(int mode_)
        This method should be called to signal the passage of time. The link will deliver appropriate number of packets, if any, at the other end (opposite from where the packet was received).
        Specified by:
        process in class NetworkElement
        Parameters:
        mode_ - the transmission mode for this link; value "0" means both-way transmission, value "1" means one-way transmission from node1 to node2, and value "2" means one-way transmission from node2 to node1
        See Also:
        NetworkElement.process(int)

      • send

        public void send(NetworkElement source_,
        Packet packet_)
        The link just accepts any new packets given to it and enqueues the new packet behind any existing packets. These packets in transit/flight will be delivered on the other end of the link after appropriate delays, when method process(int) is called.
        Parameter source_ is used to distinguish the nodes connected to the link's ends.

        At the time when a packet is enqueued, its delay is also calculated and stored in the corresponding array (packetDelaysN1toN2 or packetDelaysN2toN1).

        Note: In the current implementation when calculating the packet delay, we do not check the packet length. The transmission time transmissionTime is assumed to be the same for all packets. Of course, this is not true because TCP acknowledgment-only segments are much shorter than TCP segments carrying data. this is a TODO item.

        Specified by:
        send in class NetworkElement
        Parameters:
        source_ - the source of the packet
        packet_ - the new packet in flight on this link
        See Also:
        NetworkElement.send(NetworkElement, Packet)

      • setPropagationTime

        public void setPropagationTime(double propagationTime_)
        Parameter setter.
        Parameters:
        propagationTime_ - the propagation time to set (in simulator clock ticks)
